data.title: A Companion to Music at the Habsburg Courts in the Sixteenth and Seventeenth Centuries
data.meta_description: Abstract With the death of Francesco II Sforza on 1 November 1535, possession of the Duchy of Milan reverted to Charles V. In the succeeding years, the ducal chapel at Santa Maria della Scala and the ducal court ensemble were transformed into royal ducal ones that served the local governors, and some Milanese musicians were even employed in the royal chapel of the Spanish Habsburgs. Yet Habsburg sovereignty was musically communicated largely through the progressions and funerals of the Habsburg rulers and the festivities celebrating the birth of Habsburg princes. Royal entries and funerals of the Habsburgs in Milan were structured according to prescribed formulas that accentuated an imperial heritage extending from ancient Rome, but the mode of delivery and its corresponding content reflected current trends and featured the composition and performance of local musicians, particularly those employed at the Duomo, Santa Maria della Scala, and in the gubernatorial court chapel. Using as points of departure the progressions into Milan of Charles V (1541), Philip II (1548), Margarita of Austria (1598), and Mariana of Austria (1549), the obsequies in Milan for Charles V (1559), Anna of Austria (1581), and Philip III (1621), and the Milanese celebrations for the birth of the future Philip IV (1605), this chapter explores the use of music and musical entertainments in expressing Habsburg sovereignty in Milan.
data.text:
Abstract

With the death of Francesco II Sforza on 1 November 1535, possession of the Duchy of Milan reverted to Charles V. In the succeeding years, the ducal chapel at Santa Maria della Scala and the ducal court ensemble were transformed into royal ducal ones that served the local governors, and some Milanese musicians were even employed in the royal chapel of the Spanish Habsburgs. Yet Habsburg sovereignty was musically communicated largely through the progressions and funerals of the Habsburg rulers and the festivities celebrating the birth of Habsburg princes. Royal entries and funerals of the Habsburgs in Milan were structured according to prescribed formulas that accentuated an imperial heritage extending from ancient Rome, but the mode of delivery and its corresponding content reflected current trends and featured the composition and performance of local musicians, particularly those employed at the Duomo, Santa Maria della Scala, and in the gubernatorial court chapel. Using as points of departure the progressions into Milan of Charles V (1541), Philip II (1548), Margarita of Austria (1598), and Mariana of Austria (1549), the obsequies in Milan for Charles V (1559), Anna of Austria (1581), and Philip III (1621), and the Milanese celebrations for the birth of the future Philip IV (1605), this chapter explores the use of music and musical entertainments in expressing Habsburg sovereignty in Milan.
